_**The Last of the Mohicans**_ is a 1992 American [epic](/wiki/Epic_film "Epic
film") [historical drama](/wiki/List_of_historical_drama_films "List of
historical drama films"), set in 1757 during the [French and Indian
War](/wiki/French_and_Indian_War "French and Indian War"). It was directed by
[Michael Mann](/wiki/Michael_Mann_\(director\) "Michael Mann \(director\)"),
based on [James Fenimore Cooper](/wiki/James_Fenimore_Cooper "James Fenimore
Cooper")'s [eponymous 1826 novel](/wiki/The_Last_of_the_Mohicans "The Last of
the Mohicans") and [George B. Seitz](/wiki/George_B._Seitz "George B.
Seitz")'s [1936 film adaptation](/wiki/The_Last_of_the_Mohicans_\(1936_film\)
"The Last of the Mohicans \(1936 film\)"), owing more to the latter than the
novel. The film stars [Daniel Day-Lewis](/wiki/Daniel_Day-Lewis "Daniel Day-
Lewis"), [Madeleine Stowe](/wiki/Madeleine_Stowe "Madeleine Stowe"), and
[Jodhi May](/wiki/Jodhi_May "Jodhi May"), with [Russell
Means](/wiki/Russell_Means "Russell Means"), [Wes Studi](/wiki/Wes_Studi "Wes
Studi"), [Eric Schweig](/wiki/Eric_Schweig "Eric Schweig"), and [Steven
Waddington](/wiki/Steven_Waddington "Steven Waddington") in supporting roles.
It was produced by [Morgan Creek Pictures](/wiki/Morgan_Creek_Pictures "Morgan
Creek Pictures").

[The soundtrack](/wiki/The_Last_of_the_Mohicans_\(album\) "The Last of the
Mohicans \(album\)") features music by [Trevor
Jones](/wiki/Trevor_Jones_\(composer\) "Trevor Jones \(composer\)") and [Randy
Edelman](/wiki/Randy_Edelman "Randy Edelman"), and the song "I Will Find You"
by [Clannad](/wiki/Clannad_\(musical_group\) "Clannad \(musical group\)"). The
main theme of the film is taken from the tune "The Gael" by
[Scottish](/wiki/Scotland "Scotland") singer-songwriter [Dougie
MacLean](/wiki/Dougie_MacLean "Dougie MacLean"). Released on September 25,
1992 in the United States, _The Last of the Mohicans_ was met with nearly
universal praise from critics and commercial success during its box-office
run.

##
Plot[[edit](/w/index.php?title=The_Last_of_the_Mohicans_\(1992_film\)&action=edit&section=1
"Edit section: Plot")]

The story takes place in 1757, during the [French and Indian
War](/wiki/French_and_Indian_War "French and Indian War") in the [Adirondack
Mountains](/wiki/Adirondack_Mountains "Adirondack Mountains"), in the British
colony of New York. [British Army](/wiki/British_Army "British Army") Major
Duncan Heyward arrives in Albany. He has been sent to serve under Colonel
Edmund Munro, the commander of [Fort William Henry](/wiki/Fort_William_Henry
"Fort William Henry"). Heyward is given the task of escorting the colonel’s
two daughters, Cora and Alice, to their father. He is a family friend and in
love with Cora, to whom he proposes before they leave, but she does not give
him an answer.

Major Heyward, the two women, and a troop of British soldiers march through
the rugged countryside, guided by [Magua](/wiki/Magua "Magua"), a
[Huron](/wiki/Wyandot_people "Wyandot people") warrior. Magua leads the party
into an ambush. All of the soldiers are killed or wounded, but Heyward and the
women are rescued by the timely intervention of the [Mohican](/wiki/Mohican
"Mohican") chief [Chingachgook](/wiki/Chingachgook "Chingachgook"), his son
[Uncas](/wiki/Uncas "Uncas"), and his white, adopted son
"[Hawkeye](/wiki/Natty_Bumppo "Natty Bumppo")", who kill all of the ambushers
except Magua, who escapes. The rescuers agree to take the women and Heyward to
the fort. During the fight, Hawkeye noticed that Magua attempted to kill Cora
and asks Duncan if he knows why. During the trek, Cora and Hawkeye are
attracted to each other, as are Uncas and Alice.

When the party nears the fort, they find it under siege by the French and
their Huron allies. The party manages to sneak in and are greeted by Colonel
Munro, who asks Major Heyward about the requested, desperately needed
reinforcements. While there, Cora and Hawkeye share a passionate kiss, and
Heyward becomes jealous. In response, Cora finally tells him she will not
marry him.

When Munro refuses to allow the militiamen to sneak away to defend their own
families and homes, as he had earlier promised, Hawkeye arranges it anyway. He
stays, however, and is condemned to death. Before that happens, during a
parlay, French general [Louis-Joseph de Montcalm](/wiki/Louis-
Joseph_de_Montcalm "Louis-Joseph de Montcalm") shows Munro an intercepted
message which states that no reinforcements have been sent. Montcalm offers to
allow the British to evacuate the fort with honor, keeping their weapons.
Munro has little choice but to accept. However, Magua, a French ally, is
furious at this arrangement. He harbors great hatred for Munro, blaming him
for past wrongs done to him and his family.

The following day, Colonel Munro, his soldiers, and their women and children
leave the fort. Magua and his Huron warriors ambush them. Magua personally
kills Munro. Hawkeye and the Mohicans fight their way out, leading Cora,
Alice, and Heyward to temporary safety. Later, however, Magua captures the
major and the women. Magua takes his prisoners to a Huron settlement and
addresses its [sachem](/wiki/Sachem "Sachem"). He is interrupted by Hawkeye,
who comes in alone to plead for their lives.

The sachem rules that Heyward be returned to the British, Alice given to
Magua, and Cora [burned alive](/wiki/Execution_by_burning "Execution by
burning"). Hawkeye, for his great bravery, may leave unharmed. Hawkeye tells
Heyward, who is serving as translator, to beg the sachem to let Hawkeye take
Cora's place. Instead, Heyward trades his own life for Cora’s.

Once Cora and Hawkeye are far enough away, Hawkeye shoots Heyward to end his
suffering. Chingachgook, Uncas, and Hawkeye then set out after Magua's party
to free Alice. Uncas races ahead and engages Magua in personal combat, but is
killed. Alice chooses to step off the cliff to her death rather than go to the
beckoning Magua. While Hawkeye holds Magua's remaining men at bay,
Chingachgook duels Magua and avenges his son. Chingachgook prays to the [Great
Spirit](/wiki/Great_Spirit "Great Spirit") to receive Uncas, calling himself
"the last of the Mohicans".

##
Props[[edit](/w/index.php?title=The_Last_of_the_Mohicans_\(1992_film\)&action=edit&section=4
"Edit section: Props")]

Much care was taken with recreating accurate costumes and props. American
Bladesmith Society master bladesmith [Daniel Winkler](/wiki/Daniel_Winkler
"Daniel Winkler") made the [tomahawks](/wiki/Tomahawk_\(axe\) "Tomahawk
\(axe\)") used in the film and knifemaker Randall King made the knives.[3]
Wayne Watson is the maker of Hawkeye's "Killdeer" rifle used in the film. The
[gunstock war club](/wiki/Gunstock_war_club "Gunstock war club") made for
Chingachgook was created by Jim Yellow Eagle. Magua's tomahawk was made by
Fred A. Mitchell of Odin Forge & Fabrication.

Costumes were originally designed by multiple Academy Award winner [James
Acheson](/wiki/James_Acheson "James Acheson"), but he left the film and had
his name removed because of artistic differences with Mann. Designer [Elsa
Zamparelli](/wiki/Elsa_Zamparelli "Elsa Zamparelli") was brought in to finish.

Despite the film taking place in upstate [New York](/wiki/New_York_\(state\)
"New York \(state\)"), according to the film credits, it was filmed mostly in
the [Blue Ridge Mountains](/wiki/Blue_Ridge_Mountains "Blue Ridge Mountains")
of [North Carolina](/wiki/North_Carolina "North Carolina"). Locations used
include [Lake James](/wiki/Lake_James "Lake James"), [Chimney Rock
Park](/wiki/Chimney_Rock_Park "Chimney Rock Park") and [The Biltmore
Estate](/wiki/Biltmore_Estate "Biltmore Estate"). Some of the waterfalls that
were used in the movie include [Hooker Falls](/wiki/Hooker_Falls "Hooker
Falls"), [Triple Falls](/wiki/Triple_Falls_\(DuPont_State_Forest\) "Triple
Falls \(DuPont State Forest\)"), [Bridal Veil
Falls](/wiki/Bridal_Veil_Falls_\(DuPont_State_Forest\) "Bridal Veil Falls
\(DuPont State Forest\)"), and [High
Falls](/wiki/High_Falls_\(DuPont_State_Forest\) "High Falls \(DuPont State
Forest\)"), all located in the [DuPont State Recreational
Forest](/wiki/DuPont_State_Forest "DuPont State Forest"). Another of these
falls was [Linville Falls](/wiki/Linville_Falls "Linville Falls"), in the
mountains of North Carolina. Scenes of Albany were shot in Asheville, NC at
The Manor on Charlotte St.

## Reception and
honors[[edit](/w/index.php?title=The_Last_of_the_Mohicans_\(1992_film\)&action=edit&section=6
"Edit section: Reception and honors")]

_The Last of the Mohicans_ opened to general acclaim, with critics praising
the film for its cinematography and music. Critic [Roger
Ebert](/wiki/Roger_Ebert "Roger Ebert") of the _[Chicago Sun-
Times](/wiki/Chicago_Sun-Times "Chicago Sun-Times")_ gave the film three stars
and called it "quite an improvement on Cooper's all but unreadable book, and a
worthy successor to the [Randolph Scott](/wiki/Randolph_Scott "Randolph
Scott") [version](/wiki/The_Last_of_the_Mohicans_\(1936_film\) "The Last of
the Mohicans \(1936 film\)")," going on to say that "_The Last of the
Mohicans_ is not as authentic and uncompromised as it claims to be — more of a
matinee fantasy than it wants to admit — but it is probably more entertaining
as a result."[4]

Desson Howe of _[The Washington Post](/wiki/The_Washington_Post "The
Washington Post")_ classified the film as "glam-opera" and "the MTV version of
gothic romance".[5] Rita Kempley of the Post recognized the "heavy drama,"
writing that the film "sets new standards when it comes to pent-up passion",
but commented positively on the "spectacular scenery".[6]

_The Last of the Mohicans_ is certified "Fresh" at the film site [Rotten
Tomatoes](/wiki/Rotten_Tomatoes "Rotten Tomatoes"), with a positive rating of
94% (34 reviews out of 35 counted fresh).[7]

The film won the [Academy Award for Best
Sound](/wiki/Academy_Award_for_Best_Sound "Academy Award for Best Sound")
([Chris Jenkins](/wiki/Chris_Jenkins_\(sound_engineer\) "Chris Jenkins \(sound
engineer\)"), [Doug Hemphill](/wiki/Doug_Hemphill "Doug Hemphill"), [Mark
Smith](/wiki/Mark_Smith_\(sound_engineer\) "Mark Smith \(sound engineer\)"),
[Simon Kaye](/wiki/Simon_Kaye "Simon Kaye")).[8]

**[American Film Institute](/wiki/American_Film_Institute "American Film
Institute") recognition:**

  * [AFI's 100 Years...100 Heroes and Villains](/wiki/AFI%27s_100_Years...100_Heroes_and_Villains "AFI's 100 Years...100 Heroes and Villains"): 
    * Hawkeye - Nominated Hero[9]

### Box
office[[edit](/w/index.php?title=The_Last_of_the_Mohicans_\(1992_film\)&action=edit&section=7
"Edit section: Box office")]

The film opened in the United States on September 25, 1992, in 1,856 theaters.
It was the number 1 movie on its opening weekend.[10][11] By the end of its
first weekend, _The Last of the Mohicans_ had generated $10,976,661, and by
the end of its domestic run, the film had made $75,505,856.[2] It was ranked
the 17th highest-grossing film of 1992 in the United States.[12]

## Alternate
versions[[edit](/w/index.php?title=The_Last_of_the_Mohicans_\(1992_film\)&action=edit&section=8
"Edit section: Alternate versions")]

The film was released theatrically in 1992 at a length of 112 minutes. It was
released at this length on VHS in the U.S. It was re-edited to a length of 117
minutes[13] for its U.S. DVD release on November 23, 1999,[14] which was
billed as the "Director's Expanded Edition". It was again re-edited for its
U.S. Blu-ray release on October 5, 2010,[15] this time billed as the
"Director's Definitive Cut", with a length of 114 mins.[16]
